content: Okay guys, help me understand something here... Why is it that when your wife tells you something having to do with say, your back and how you shouldn't let the fact that you're in pain keep you from your life, you don't listen at all But when the DOCTOR or a COMPLETE STRANGER says the same thing, it clicks? What the hell is that about?
reply: Okay guys, help me understand something here... Why is it that when your wife tells you something having to do with say, your back and how you shouldn't let the fact that you're in pain keep you from your life, you don't listen at all But when the DOCTOR or a COMPLETE STRANGER says the same thing, it clicks? What the hell is that about?
title: A question about Men...

content: Cuz a guy got to be tough for his wife - Rock of Gibraltar - even if he be dying inside . . . "It's only a flesh wound! I've had worse! Slap a hot iron on it, a tobacco poultice, and quit burnin' daylight, daggumit!! Yahah! Yahah!!" Wandering and Wondering
reply: Cuz a guy got to be tough for his wife - Rock of Gibraltar - even if he be dying inside . . . "It's only a flesh wound! I've had worse! Slap a hot iron on it, a tobacco poultice, and quit burnin' daylight, daggumit!! Yahah! Yahah!!" Wandering and Wondering
title: A question about Men...

content: This is because the communication between man and wife is a wild mix of hidden meanings, muttered cryptic intonations and veiled enigmatic phrases that can interpreted in a myriad of ways ranging from the Illiad in original Greek to 'The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog.' As Churchill would say, they (the Soviets or women, take your pick) are "An enigma, wrapped in a riddle, shrouded in mystery." For example, a recent $1000 upgrade of our master bathroom started like this: My wife walked into our bathroom and stated innocently (right!): "I hate this wallpaper" After 26 years I should have seen it coming. Instead I foolishly said the first thing that popped in my head; "So, what do you want me to do about it?"* Three weeks later, I finally finished installing the new floor, floor molding, toilet, cabinet, sink, mirror, medicine cabinet, and painting the room four times, twice in the color she didn't realize she hated until it dried, and twice more in a color she could live with (in an ominously dangerous voice) "for now." I realize there may be some young unmarried or newly married men out there who missed the obvious errors in my reply, so I ennumerate them for you now: Error #1. I replied. The proper response should have been feigned deafness, a noncommital grunt of some kind or silence accompanied by a rapid exit to the far side of the house and immediate start of the disposal, lawn mower, chainsaw, motorcycle, skillsaw or jet engine to render any further communication impossible. Error #2. I did not immediately contradict her, meaning I silently (and therefore emphatically) agreed to the unsatisfactoriness of the current (free) wallpaper,.... vanity, flooring, cabinets, mirror, lights, floorboards,... you get the picture. Error #3. I announced the immediate availability of my effort, time, money and expertise with an open-ended schedule and limitless budget....AND demanded that she set the priority, starting time and work hours for the entire project. I include this only as a guide for new and/or future husbands in order that they may formulate the proper reply to such statements. Here endeth the lesson. Sullivan013
reply: This is because the communication between man and wife is a wild mix of hidden meanings, muttered cryptic intonations and veiled enigmatic phrases that can interpreted in a myriad of ways ranging from the Illiad in original Greek to 'The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog.' As Churchill would say, they (the Soviets or women, take your pick) are "An enigma, wrapped in a riddle, shrouded in mystery." For example, a recent $1000 upgrade of our master bathroom started like this: My wife walked into our bathroom and stated innocently (right!): "I hate this wallpaper" After 26 years I should have seen it coming. Instead I foolishly said the first thing that popped in my head; "So, what do you want me to do about it?"* Three weeks later, I finally finished installing the new floor, floor molding, toilet, cabinet, sink, mirror, medicine cabinet, and painting the room four times, twice in the color she didn't realize she hated until it dried, and twice more in a color she could live with (in an ominously dangerous voice) "for now." I realize there may be some young unmarried or newly married men out there who missed the obvious errors in my reply, so I ennumerate them for you now: Error #1. I replied. The proper response should have been feigned deafness, a noncommital grunt of some kind or silence accompanied by a rapid exit to the far side of the house and immediate start of the disposal, lawn mower, chainsaw, motorcycle, skillsaw or jet engine to render any further communication impossible. Error #2. I did not immediately contradict her, meaning I silently (and therefore emphatically) agreed to the unsatisfactoriness of the current (free) wallpaper,.... vanity, flooring, cabinets, mirror, lights, floorboards,... you get the picture. Error #3. I announced the immediate availability of my effort, time, money and expertise with an open-ended schedule and limitless budget....AND demanded that she set the priority, starting time and work hours for the entire project. I include this only as a guide for new and/or future husbands in order that they may formulate the proper reply to such statements. Here endeth the lesson. Sullivan013
title: A question about Men...

content: So what makes the difference when the doc tells you/him the same thing that the wife did? Is it one of those "I know she's right but I can't let her know that" things?
reply: So what makes the difference when the doc tells you/him the same thing that the wife did? Is it one of those "I know she's right but I can't let her know that" things?
title: A question about Men...

content: Getting a second opinion? Usually the wife is younger, so there's a pecking order thing? Guys don't like to be told what to do, even if it might save their lives? (Quit Smoking!) . . . Guys are not cool with failure to come up with an idea first in the family, cuz it's their job and they're supposed to? Doctors poke big pointy needles in places not made for big pointy needles?!?!? It's just the (contrary) nature of the beast? I'm guessing, cuz I never had ANY of these problems you might be thinking about - Wandering and Wondering
reply: Getting a second opinion? Usually the wife is younger, so there's a pecking order thing? Guys don't like to be told what to do, even if it might save their lives? (Quit Smoking!) . . . Guys are not cool with failure to come up with an idea first in the family, cuz it's their job and they're supposed to? Doctors poke big pointy needles in places not made for big pointy needles?!?!? It's just the (contrary) nature of the beast? I'm guessing, cuz I never had ANY of these problems you might be thinking about - Wandering and Wondering
title: A question about Men...

content: quote: Originally posted by armywifefigueroa: So what makes the difference when the doc tells you/him the same thing that the wife did? Is it one of those "I know she's right but I can't let her know that" things? Because when a doctor says it, it is sound medical advice. When a wife says it, it is nagging. "When you look into an abyss, the abyss also looks into you." ~~ Friedrich Nietzsche

reply: Because when a doctor says it, it is sound medical advice. When a wife says it, it is nagging. "When you look into an abyss, the abyss also looks into you." ~~ Friedrich Nietzsche

content: Yea yea yea, Dennis is an old Marine and he is indestructable..... Until he started having back problems and had surgery. He is now realizing that he is human............ AND he listens to me and he now knows his limitations too.
reply: Yea yea yea, Dennis is an old Marine and he is indestructable..... Until he started having back problems and had surgery. He is now realizing that he is human............ AND he listens to me and he now knows his limitations too.
title: A question about Men...

content: Basically, we have all our lives, not only taken care of ourselves, but usually our family too. As we get older, we deep down inside, we can't do some of the thigns we used to, but we BS our way through it. You telling him he is jacked up, sounds like yada,yada,yada. He knows it too, he doesn't need you to verify it for him. When it gets so bad, the doc is involved, then it's a no chit and it sinks in. Women as much as we love them, we don't understand, and never will. You say and do thigns that are illogical. So we tend to nod and grunt in our responses. My humble .02

title: A question about Men...

content: quote: Originally posted by armywifefigueroa: So what makes the difference when the doc tells you/him the same thing that the wife did? Is it one of those "I know she's right but I can't let her know that" things? Quite the opposite, we allow you to slip in an "I told you so", thus allowing you a false sense of superiority. We then are allowed to play up our injury or ailment to the fullest. We get couch time, the remote & our loving wives to fetch us a beer, because we can't because they are right & we must now watch out for our delicate condition!!! PS, my wife thoruoghly hates computers & will never see this post. I may be dumb, but I'm not stupid!
quote: Originally posted by armywifefigueroa: So what makes the difference when the doc tells you/him the same thing that the wife did? Is it one of those "I know she's right but I can't let her know that" things?

PS, my wife thoruoghly hates computers & will never see this post. I may be dumb, but I'm not stupid!

reply: This is because the communication between man and wife is a wild mix of hidden meanings, muttered cryptic intonations and veiled enigmatic phrases that can interpreted in a myriad of ways ranging from the Illiad in original Greek to 'The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog.' As Churchill would say, they (the Soviets or women, take your pick) are "An enigma, wrapped in a riddle, shrouded in mystery." For example, a recent $1000 upgrade of our master bathroom started like this: My wife walked into our bathroom and stated innocently (right!): "I hate this wallpaper" After 26 years I should have seen it coming. Instead I foolishly said the first thing that popped in my head; "So, what do you want me to do about it?"* Three weeks later, I finally finished installing the new floor, floor molding, toilet, cabinet, sink, mirror, medicine cabinet, and painting the room four times, twice in the color she didn't realize she hated until it dried, and twice more in a color she could live with (in an ominously dangerous voice) "for now." I realize there may be some young unmarried or newly married men out there who missed the obvious errors in my reply, so I ennumerate them for you now: Error #1. I replied. The proper response should have been feigned deafness, a noncommital grunt of some kind or silence accompanied by a rapid exit to the far side of the house and immediate start of the disposal, lawn mower, chainsaw, motorcycle, skillsaw or jet engine to render any further communication impossible. Error #2. I did not immediately contradict her, meaning I silently (and therefore emphatically) agreed to the unsatisfactoriness of the current (free) wallpaper,.... vanity, flooring, cabinets, mirror, lights, floorboards,... you get the picture. Error #3. I announced the immediate availability of my effort, time, money and expertise with an open-ended schedule and limitless budget....AND demanded that she set the priority, starting time and work hours for the entire project. I include this only as a guide for new and/or future husbands in order that they may formulate the proper reply to such statements. Here endeth the lesson. Sullivan013
title: A question about Men...

content: So what makes the difference when the doc tells you/him the same thing that the wife did? Is it one of those "I know she's right but I can't let her know that" things?

content: Getting a second opinion? Usually the wife is younger, so there's a pecking order thing? Guys don't like to be told what to do, even if it might save their lives? (Quit Smoking!) . . . Guys are not cool with failure to come up with an idea first in the family, cuz it's their job and they're supposed to? Doctors poke big pointy needles in places not made for big pointy needles?!?!? It's just the (contrary) nature of the beast? I'm guessing, cuz I never had ANY of these problems you might be thinking about - Wandering and Wondering

content: Basically, we have all our lives, not only taken care of ourselves, but usually our family too. As we get older, we deep down inside, we can't do some of the thigns we used to, but we BS our way through it. You telling him he is jacked up, sounds like yada,yada,yada. He knows it too, he doesn't need you to verify it for him. When it gets so bad, the doc is involved, then it's a no chit and it sinks in. Women as much as we love them, we don't understand, and never will. You say and do thigns that are illogical. So we tend to nod and grunt in our responses. My humble .02

content: quote: Originally posted by armywifefigueroa: So what makes the difference when the doc tells you/him the same thing that the wife did? Is it one of those "I know she's right but I can't let her know that" things? Quite the opposite, we allow you to slip in an "I told you so", thus allowing you a false sense of superiority. We then are allowed to play up our injury or ailment to the fullest. We get couch time, the remote & our loving wives to fetch us a beer, because we can't because they are right & we must now watch out for our delicate condition!!! PS, my wife thoruoghly hates computers & will never see this post. I may be dumb, but I'm not stupid!
